Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2008 08:44PM NikiC wrote: I had a bilateral also but without lymph nodes removed because mine was profylactic.  It seems the third week was the charm.  I was able to do mostly anything and the pain was gone except for some skin sensitivity on my chest (I still have a little but it's getting better).  I only had 2 drains in for a week and I didn't find it bothersome at all and also it didn't hurt to have them removed which only took a few seconds.  I think you'll do just fine.  Don't be afraid to take your pain meds, it helps to get through it,  Good luck.
Posts.Title: Question about recovery time PeaceCat PeaceCat

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2009 09:22PM NikiC wrote: I choose a prophylactic BMX because of atypia cells, family history and BRCA mutation.  My MRI showed the atypia cells in the left breast so I had an incisional biopsy to remove them.  If I hadn't opted for the mastectomy (I had no cancer) I just would of went home and continued screening and maybe taken Tamoxifen which was recommended but I didn't want.  I also did not want to worry about someday getting cancer and having to go through possible chemo.  So I chose the surgery with biopsy results that yielded more atypia cells in BOTH breasts.  I think it would have just been a matter of time before these cells turned into cancer.  Now I don't have the worries that I had before and am so thankful that I underwent the MX.

Posts.Title: What made you decide . . . Mantra Mantra

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2008 12:14AM NikiC wrote: Hi Danielle, I love that name, it's also my daughter's name and she's about your age.  I found out that I had the BRCA2 gene after going through a biopsy that showed I had atypia (pre-cancer).  I decided to have a bilateral mastectomy with immediate reconstruction 3 weeks ago.  My main reasons were so that I didnt have to ever go throgh chemo or radiation if I ever did develop cancer.  Also if you have the surgery without cancer (profylactic) they don't have to take out any of your lymph nodes which as I hear can cause more problems like lymphadema and longer recovery time for range of motion. The surgery was a cinch (especially since no nodes were taken out) and expanders so far are not that bad either.  Since I have no cancer and no need for further treatments I can have my expanders filled as little or as much as I want and there's no timeframe which makes it really easy.  For me the decision was a no brainer since my mom and sister both had cancer and I always knew that this is what I would do if I was ever faced with this situation.  My two daughters aged 21 and 22 said it was the right thing to do and that they think they would do the same thing if they were faced with it.  You are young however and have plenty of time to really think it through and it sounds like you have a great supportive fiance.  Good luck and I hope this helps a little.
Posts.Title: I have the Gene-Is Surgery the Answer? dandee354 Bronwen

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2009 09:40PM NikiC wrote: I did not have any cancer but due to atypia cells, family history and a genetic mutation I chose to have a bilateral mx.  You can read my story that Fox Chase Cancer Center where I was treated, wanted to do.  http://www.fccc.edu/whyChoose/successStories/breast/cerceo.html
Posts.Title: Prophylactic bilateral mx simmonba CAROLMARIE427

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2009 06:41PM NikiC wrote: Everyone is different.  I only had two drains, one in each side and they were taken out after one week.  I only felt a small pinch but no pain and then had a band-aid placed over the site.  I had no drains when I had the exchange surgery and I don't think most people do.  I hope this helps you.
Posts.Title: Drains after bilateral mastectomy-questions! SDinSDCA Alfieval

Posts.Content: NikiC wrote: I am three weeks out from having a profylactic BM and have recovered quite well except for this very uncomfortable skin hypersensitivity on my chest to the point where I can't wear ANYTHING because it feels so sore.  I have tried many different tops, tight ones that don't move, loose ones, silk ones, etc. and nothing seems to work.  Thank goodness I'm not working and am able to just go around with a blanket draped around me while at home.  When I do go out I have to take a percocet just to numb the pain a bit, but I really don't want to take them for that.  If anyone has any ideas that could help I would so appreciate it.  Thank you!  Also, if anyone else has this or had it how long does it last and it does go away right? Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Post Op Skin Hypersensitivity NikiC Ariom

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2008 06:30PM NikiC wrote: I too tested positive for an unknown variant on BRCA2.  My sister and mother did also and they both are breast cancer survivors.  We are all around 50 years old at the time of diagnosis.  As of date there are only 26 families tested that carry this mutation so I'm convinced there are probably so many different variants on BRCA1 and 2 that are'nt known yet.  I had atypia but based on my family history and the mutation decided to have a profylactic bilateral mastectomy which I always knew I would do if ever in this situation.
Posts.Title: Genetic Mutation Question shelt04 pokadot

Posts.Content: Dec 14, 2008 07:08AM NikiC wrote: Thank you and yes I did tell my PS and he said it is common and could get worse before it gets better.  I also take alot of Advil and sometimes switch it to ES Tylenol which does help a little.  Yesterday I found a loose fitting silk-like top that was a little better so I guess Ill be wearing that under things for a while.  Also as I have been reading it seems like it can last anywhere from a few weeks to months depending on the person.  Like my PS said, everyone is so different and has many different complaints so there is really no definitive answers, just have to wait and see.
Posts.Title: Post Op Skin Hypersensitivity NikiC Ariom

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2009 10:22PM NikiC wrote: samiam40:  Yea I don't know why the PS at my cancer center don't put drains in.  In any event though everything with me was fine and I never had any pain or need for meds afterwards.  Is there anyone else out there that didn't have drains after their exchange surgery?  I'm curious now.
